column2: and was in such a hurry to see the fine streets paved with gold
column3: that he ran through many of them
column4: thinking every moment to come to those that were paved with gold; for Dick had seen a guinea three times in his own little village
column5: and remembered what a lot of money it brought in change; so he thought he had nothing to do but to take up some little bits of pavement
column6: and he would then have as much money as he could wish for. Poor Dick ran till he was tired
column7: and had quite forgotten his friend the driver. At last
column9: and that every way he turned he saw nothing but dirt instead of gold
column10: he sat down in a dark corner
column11: and cried himself to sleep. Next morning
column13: he got up and walked about
column14: and asked everybody he met to give him a halfpenny to keep him from starving. At last
column15: a good-natured-looking gentleman saw how hungry he looked."Why don't you go to work
column17: answered Dick, but I do not know how to get any."
